Event refers to a set of one or more selected outcomes, usually denoted by 𝐸𝐸.

The probability of an event 𝐸𝐸 occurring is given by:

Part 1: Possibility Diagram
Previously, we learnt to calculate single event probabilities where each experiment concludes after a 
single event. Next, we will learn to handle combined event probabilities where two or more 
events occur one after another and we have to calculate the overall probability of the whole set of 
events.
A possibility diagram is a systematic way of listing all the possible outcomes of an experiment that 
involves two stages.

Part 2: Probability Tree Diagram
A Tree Diagram is a tool used to systematically displaying all the possible outcomes of a
combined event. It is a useful visual representation of the scenario and allows us to keep track 
of each probability and hence reduce error in calculation.
It is especially useful for dependent events where the subsequent event is affected by the 
occurrences of the first event.
Example:
A bag contains 3 blue token and 5 red tokens. Two tokens are taken out at random from the bag, one at 
a time, without replacement. Find the probability that 
a) both tokens are blue
b) one token is blue, one token is red

Part 3: Evaluating Probability (with or w/o diagrams)
Mutually Exclusive Events
Two outcomes/events are mutually exclusive if they cannot both occur at the same time.
For example, when we throw a dice, the outcome of obtaining a “1” and the outcome of obtaining 
a “6” are mutually exclusive because we cannot obtain both "1" and "6" at the same time.
Independent VS Dependent Events
Independent events are best illustrated in events where the object is replaced after picking.
Because the object is replaced, the probability of picking a second object will not be affected by 
the first pick.
Dependent events are best illustrated in events where the object is not replaced after picking.
As the object is not replaced, the probability of picking a second object will be affected by what 
was picked in the first pick.
Hence, for dependent events (i.e. events without replacement), we have to account and adjust for 
the object removed in the first pick before multiplying the probabilities.
Example of independent events
Two balls are randomly taken out, with replacement, from a bag of 3 red and 4 blue balls. Find the probability 
of taking out two blue balls.
𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵, 𝐵𝐵) = 4

Addition Law of Probabilities
𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴 𝒐𝒐𝒐𝒐 𝐵𝐵) = 𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴) + 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵)
For example:
𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1 6 𝑎𝑎 ℎ ) = 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1) + 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 6)
= 1
6
+ 1
6
 
= 1
3
In short, the word “or” is associated with “+” when handling probabilities.
However, the two events/outcomes 𝐴𝐴 and 𝐵𝐵 must be mutually exclusive for this law to be true.
Multiplication Law of Probabilities
𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴 𝐵𝐵) = 𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴) × 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵)
For example: 
𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1 𝑚𝑚 𝑓𝑓 ℎ 𝑎𝑎 𝑎𝑎 𝑎𝑎 6 𝑚𝑚 ℎ )
= 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1 𝑓𝑓 ℎ ) × 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 6 ℎ )
= 1
6
×
1
6
 
= 1
36
In short, the word “and” is associated with “×” (multiplication) when handling probabilities.
However, the two events/outcomes 𝐴𝐴 and 𝐵𝐵 must be independent for this law to be true.

28.

 𝑛𝑛2 − 15𝑛𝑛 + 56 = 6
 𝑛𝑛2 − 15𝑛𝑛 + 50 = 0

 (𝑛𝑛 − 5)(𝑛𝑛 − 10) = 0
 𝑛𝑛 − 5 = 0 or 𝑛𝑛 − 10 = 0

 There are 3 black buttons in the bag

probability that a third blue stick is picked is 1
4 , find the value of 𝑥𝑥.

after the other, without replacement.
a. Draw a possibility diagram to represent the outcomes.

i. both counters have numbers less than 3,
ii. neither counters has an even number,
iii. the sum of the numbers is 10,
iv. the product of the numbers is less than 6.

parts:
Based on **Part 1: Possibility Diagram** in the attached notes. fileciteturn0file0

## 10 Questions

### 1) Cards (Sum, without replacement)
A box contains 5 identical cards numbered **1, 2, 4, 7, 8**. Two cards are drawn at random, one after another, **without replacement**. The **sum** is recorded.

**(a)** Copy and complete the possibility diagram (write **X** on the diagonal).

| 1st \ 2nd | 1 | 2 | 4 | 7 | 8 |
|---|---:|---:|---:|---:|---:|
| **1** | X |  |  |  |  |
| **2** |  | X |  |  |  |
| **4** |  |  | X |  |  |
| **7** |  |  |  | X |  |
| **8** |  |  |  |  | X |

**(b)** Find \(P(\text{sum}=9)\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{sum is prime})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{sum}\ge 10)\).  
**(e)** Find \(P(\text{sum is even})\).

---

### 2) Dice (Union of events)
Two unbiased six-sided dice are thrown.

Let \(A\): “sum is a **prime** number”.  
Let \(B\): “difference (larger − smaller) is **2**”.

Find \(P(A)\), \(P(B)\), \(P(A\cap B)\), \(P(A\cup B)\).

---

### 3) Balls (Product + “at least” via complement)
A bag contains 5 balls numbered **1, 2, 4, 5, 9**. Two balls are drawn, one after another, **without replacement**. The **product** is recorded.

Find the probability that the product is  
**(a)** a perfect square,  
**(b)** a multiple of 10,  
**(c)** greater than 20,  
**(d)** **at least one** ball drawn is numbered 9.

---

### 4) Two spinners (Sum table)
Spinner \(P\) has outcomes **2, 4, 6, 8** (equally likely).  
Spinner \(Q\) has outcomes **1, 3, 5** (equally likely).  
Each spinner is spun once. The **sum** is recorded.

**(a)** Complete the possibility diagram.

| \(P\)\(\backslash\)\(Q\) | 1 | 3 | 5 |
|---|---:|---:|---:|
| **2** |  |  |  |
| **4** |  |  |  |
| **6** |  |  |  |
| **8** |  |  |  |

**(b)** Find \(P(\text{sum is prime})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{sum is a multiple of 3})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{sum} > 10)\).  
**(e)** Find \(P(\text{sum is odd})\).

---

### 5) Cards (Difference table, without replacement)
A box contains 4 cards numbered **1, 3, 4, 6**. Two cards are drawn, one after another, **without replacement**. The **difference** (larger − smaller) is recorded.

**(a)** Complete the possibility diagram (write **X** on the diagonal).

| 1st \ 2nd | 1 | 3 | 4 | 6 |
|---|---:|---:|---:|---:|
| **1** | X |  |  |  |
| **3** |  | X |  |  |
| **4** |  |  | X |  |
| **6** |  |  |  | X |

**(b)** Find \(P(\text{difference}=1)\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{difference is prime})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{difference}\le 2)\).

---

### 6) Coloured balls (Mixed colours, without replacement)
A bag contains **2 red**, **3 blue**, and **1 green** ball. Two balls are drawn, one after another, **without replacement**.

Find the probability that  
**(a)** both balls are blue,  
**(b)** the two balls are different colours,  
**(c)** at most one blue ball is drawn,  
**(d)** at least one green ball is drawn.

---

### 7) With vs without replacement (compare probabilities)
A box contains 4 cards numbered **1, 2, 4, 7**. Two cards are drawn.

**(a)** Without replacement, find \(P(\text{sum} > 8)\).  
**(b)** With replacement, find \(P(\text{sum} > 8)\).  
**(c)** A student says (b) must be larger because “there are more favourable outcomes”. Is the student correct?

---

### 8) Dice (Product properties)
Two unbiased six-sided dice are thrown.

Find the probability that the **product** is  
**(a)** 12,  
**(b)** a multiple of 5,  
**(c)** a perfect square.

---

### 9) Two-digit number from digits (without replacement)
Cards numbered **1 to 9** are placed in a bag. Two cards are drawn, one after another, **without replacement**, and a **two-digit number** is formed (first draw = tens digit).

Find the probability that the number is  
**(a)** divisible by 4,  
**(b)** divisible by 3 **or** 5.

---

### 10) Three dice (counting)
Three unbiased six-sided dice are thrown.

Find the probability that  
**(a)** exactly two dice show the same number,  
**(b)** all three numbers are different and can be arranged to form an arithmetic progression.

---

## Very concise answers

**1(a)**  
| 1st \ 2nd | 1 | 2 | 4 | 7 | 8 |
|---|---:|---:|---:|---:|---:|
| **1** | X | 3 | 5 | 8 | 9 |
| **2** | 3 | X | 6 | 9 | 10 |
| **4** | 5 | 6 | X | 11 | 12 |
| **7** | 8 | 9 | 11 | X | 15 |
| **8** | 9 | 10 | 12 | 15 | X |

**1(b)** \( \frac{1}{5} \) **1(c)** \( \frac{3}{10} \) **1(d)** \( \frac{2}{5} \) **1(e)** \( \frac{2}{5} \)

**2** \(P(A)=\frac{5}{12}\), \(P(B)=\frac{2}{9}\), \(P(A\cap B)=0\), \(P(A\cup B)=\frac{23}{36}\)

**3(a)** \( \frac{3}{10} \) **3(b)** \( \frac{1}{5} \) **3(c)** \( \frac{1}{5} \) **3(d)** \( \frac{2}{5} \)

**4(a)**  
| \(P\)\(\backslash\)\(Q\) | 1 | 3 | 5 |
|---|---:|---:|---:|
| **2** | 3 | 5 | 7 |
| **4** | 5 | 7 | 9 |
| **6** | 7 | 9 | 11 |
| **8** | 9 | 11 | 13 |

**4(b)** \( \frac{3}{4} \) **4(c)** \( \frac{1}{3} \) **4(d)** \( \frac{1}{4} \) **4(e)** \(1\)

**5(a)**  
| 1st \ 2nd | 1 | 3 | 4 | 6 |
|---|---:|---:|---:|---:|
| **1** | X | 2 | 3 | 5 |
| **3** | 2 | X | 1 | 3 |
| **4** | 3 | 1 | X | 2 |
| **6** | 5 | 3 | 2 | X |

**5(b)** \( \frac{1}{6} \) **5(c)** \( \frac{5}{6} \) **5(d)** \( \frac{1}{2} \)

**6(a)** \( \frac{1}{5} \) **6(b)** \( \frac{11}{15} \) **6(c)** \( \frac{4}{5} \) **6(d)** \( \frac{1}{3} \)

**7(a)** \( \frac{1}{3} \) **7(b)** \( \frac{5}{16} \) **7(c)** No (since \( \frac{5}{16}<\frac{1}{3}\))  

**8(a)** \( \frac{1}{9} \) **8(b)** \( \frac{11}{36} \) **8(c)** \( \frac{2}{9} \)

**9(a)** \( \frac{2}{9} \) **9(b)** \( \frac{29}{72} \)

**10(a)** \( \frac{5}{12} \) **10(b)** \( \frac{1}{6} \)

Devise 12 questions based on Part 2 on the attached lecture notes. 

- Target Difficulty level: Medium to Hard 
- Ensure your 12 questions provide comphensive coverage of the types of questions on Part 2 
- Adhere to the same style and pedagogy. 
- Do not draw diagrams in your questions, but include tables where relevant.
- For questions involving probability trees, ask the student to draw the full tree. Do not include any part of the tree in your question. Focus solely on describing in woeds the problem to be solved. 

Include very concise answers. You can leave out all diagrams including trees in your answer, even if you had asked students to draw trees.

[L89] Part 3: Evaluating Probability (with or w/o diagrams)
[L90] Mutually Exclusive Events
[L91] Two outcomes/events are mutually exclusive if they cannot both occur at the same time.
[L92] For example, when we throw a dice, the outcome of obtaining a “1” and the outcome of obtaining 
[L93] a “6” are mutually exclusive because we cannot obtain both "1" and "6" at the same time.
[L94] Independent VS Dependent Events
[L95] Independent events are best illustrated in events where the object is replaced after picking.
[L96] Because the object is replaced, the probability of picking a second object will not be affected by 
[L97] the first pick.
[L98] Dependent events are best illustrated in events where the object is not replaced after picking.
[L99] As the object is not replaced, the probability of picking a second object will be affected by what 
[L100] was picked in the first pick.
[L101] Hence, for dependent events (i.e. events without replacement), we have to account and adjust for 
[L102] the object removed in the first pick before multiplying the probabilities.
[L103] Example of independent events
[L104] Two balls are randomly taken out, with replacement, from a bag of 3 red and 4 blue balls. Find the probability 
[L105] of taking out two blue balls.
[L106] 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵, 𝐵𝐵) = 4
[L107] 7
[L108] ×
[L109] 4
[L110] 7 = 16
[L111] 49
[L112] The probability of drawing the second blue ball �
[L113] 4
[L114] 7
[L115] � is same as the first blue ball �
[L116] 4
[L117] 7
[L118] �. 
[L119] The probability of the second event is unaffected by the first event. These are independent events
[L120] Example of dependent events
[L121] Two balls are randomly taken out, without replacement, from a bag of 3 red and 4 blue balls. Find the 
[L122] probability of taking out two blue balls.
[L123] 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵, 𝐵𝐵) = 4
[L124] 7
[L125] ×
[L126] 3
[L127] 6 = 2
[L128] 7
[L129] The probability of drawing the second blue ball �
[L130] 3
[L131] 6
[L132] � is different from the first blue ball �
[L133] 4
[L134] 7
[L135] �.

[L20] A Tree Diagram is a tool used to systematically displaying all the possible outcomes of a
[L21] combined event. It is a useful visual representation of the scenario and allows us to keep track

[L23] It is especially useful for dependent events where the subsequent event is affected by the 
[L24] occurrences of the first event.

[L60] Part 2: Probability Tree Diagram
[L61] A Tree Diagram is a tool used to systematically displaying all the possible outcomes of a
[L62] combined event. It is a useful visual representation of the scenario and allows us to keep track 
[L63] of each probability and hence reduce error in calculation.
[L64] It is especially useful for dependent events where the subsequent event is affected by the 
[L65] occurrences of the first event.
[L66] Example:
[L67] A bag contains 3 blue token and 5 red tokens. Two tokens are taken out at random from the bag, one at 
[L68] a time, without replacement. Find the probability that 
[L69] a) both tokens are blue
[L70] b) one token is blue, one token is red
[L71] a) 𝑃𝑃( 𝑏𝑏ℎ 𝑡𝑡 𝑎𝑎 𝑏𝑏 ) = 3

[L91] Evaluate Probabilities at the end of a tree line
[L92] To find the probability of an outcome, multiply the probability along the tree branches for this 
[L93] outcome.

[L33] Part 0: Sec 2 Probability Recap (Single Event)
[L34] Probability
[L35] Sample space is the set of all possible outcomes, usually denoted by 𝑆𝑆.
[L36] Event refers to a set of one or more selected outcomes, usually denoted by 𝐸𝐸.
[L37] Probability is a measure of the chance of the occurrence of an event.
[L38] The probability of an event 𝐸𝐸 occurring is given by:
[L39] 𝑃𝑃(𝐸𝐸) = 𝑛𝑛(𝐸𝐸)

[L48] Original probability of drawing a black ball: 𝑥𝑥
[L49] 25
[L50] New probability of drawing a black ball: 𝑥𝑥−5
[L51] 20
[L52] The original number of black balls:

[L64]  𝑥𝑥 = 15

[L210] Previously, we learnt to calculate single event probabilities where each experiment concludes after a 
[L211] single event. Next, we will learn to handle combined event probabilities where two or more 
[L212] events occur one after another and we have to calculate the overall probability of the whole set of 
[L213] events.

[L215] involves two stages.

[L750] Part 3: Evaluating Probability (with or w/o diagrams)
[L751] Mutually Exclusive Events
[L752] Two outcomes/events are mutually exclusive if they cannot both occur at the same time.
[L753] For example, when we throw a dice, the outcome of obtaining a “1” and the outcome of obtaining 
[L754] a “6” are mutually exclusive because we cannot obtain both "1" and "6" at the same time.
[L755] Independent VS Dependent Events
[L756] Independent events are best illustrated in events where the object is replaced after picking.
[L757] Because the object is replaced, the probability of picking a second object will not be affected by 
[L758] the first pick.
[L759] Dependent events are best illustrated in events where the object is not replaced after picking.
[L760] As the object is not replaced, the probability of picking a second object will be affected by what 
[L761] was picked in the first pick.
[L762] Hence, for dependent events (i.e. events without replacement), we have to account and adjust for 
[L763] the object removed in the first pick before multiplying the probabilities.
[L764] Example of independent events
[L765] Two balls are randomly taken out, with replacement, from a bag of 3 red and 4 blue balls. Find the probability 
[L766] of taking out two blue balls.
[L767] 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵, 𝐵𝐵) = 4
[L768] 7

[L770] 4
[L771] 7 = 16

[L774] 4
[L775] 7
[L776] � is same as the first blue ball �
[L777] 4
[L778] 7
[L779] �. 
[L780] The probability of the second event is unaffected by the first event. These are independent events
[L781] Example of dependent events
[L782] Two balls are randomly taken out, without replacement, from a bag of 3 red and 4 blue balls. Find the 
[L783] probability of taking out two blue balls.
[L784] 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵, 𝐵𝐵) = 4
[L785] 7

[L788] 6 = 2

[L791] 3

[L796] �. 
[L797] The probability of the second event is affected by the first event. There are dependent events.

[L801] Addition Law of Probabilities
[L802] 𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴 𝒐𝒐𝒐𝒐 𝐵𝐵) = 𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴) + 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵)
[L803] For example:
[L804] 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1 6 𝑎𝑎 ℎ ) = 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1) + 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 6)
[L805] = 1
[L806] 6
[L807] + 1
[L808] 6
[L809]  
[L810] = 1
[L811] 3
[L812] In short, the word “or” is associated with “+” when handling probabilities.
[L813] However, the two events/outcomes 𝐴𝐴 and 𝐵𝐵 must be mutually exclusive for this law to be true.
[L814] Multiplication Law of Probabilities
[L815] 𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴 𝐵𝐵) = 𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴) × 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵)
[L816] For example: 
[L817] 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1 𝑚𝑚 𝑓𝑓 ℎ 𝑎𝑎 𝑎𝑎 𝑎𝑎 6 𝑚𝑚 ℎ )
[L818] = 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1 𝑓𝑓 ℎ ) × 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 6 ℎ )
[L819] = 1
[L820] 6
[L821] ×
[L822] 1
[L823] 6
[L824]  
[L825] = 1
[L826] 36
[L827] In short, the word “and” is associated with “×” (multiplication) when handling probabilities.
[L828] However, the two events/outcomes 𝐴𝐴 and 𝐵𝐵 must be independent for this law to be true.

content.text:
from fractions import Fraction
import itertools, math
# Q7 counts
g,y,r = 5,4,3
total = g+y+r
# enumerate ordered sequences of length 3 without replacement from multiset
# approach: compute probability via sequential formula for each sequence.
def prob_sequence(seq):
    # seq: list of colors 'G','Y','R'
    cg,cy,cr = g,y,r
    t = total
    p = Fraction(1,1)
    for s in seq:
        if s=='G':
            p *= Fraction(cg,t)
            cg -= 1
        elif s=='Y':
            p *= Fraction(cy,t)
            cy -= 1
        else:
            p *= Fraction(cr,t)
            cr -= 1
        t -= 1
    return p

colors = ['G','Y','R']
# generate all sequences of length 3 with constraints not exceeding counts
seqs=[]
for seq in itertools.product(colors, repeat=3):
    # check counts
    if seq.count('G')<=g and seq.count('Y')<=y and seq.count('R')<=r:
        seqs.append(seq)
len(seqs)

    p=Fraction(1,1)
    for s in seq:
        if s=='R':
            p*=Fraction(cr,t); cr-=1
        elif s=='B':
            p*=Fraction(cb,t); cb-=1
        else:

candidates=[]
for m in range(2,9): # blue count
    for x in range(1,13): # red count
        p = Fraction(x,x+m)*Fraction(x,x+m) + Fraction(m,x+m)*Fraction(x,x+m-1)
        # simplify and record if denom small
        if p.denominator<=60:
            candidates.append((m,x,p))
# sort by denominator
candidates_sorted=sorted(candidates, key=lambda t:(t[2].denominator, t[2].numerator))
candidates_sorted[:30]

parts:
Based on **Part 2: Probability Tree Diagram** in the attached notes. fileciteturn2file0L394-L401

## 12 Questions

### 1) With replacement (2 draws)
A bag contains the following balls:

| Colour | Red | Yellow |
|---|---:|---:|
| Number of balls | 5 | 3 |

A ball is drawn at random, **replaced**, then a second ball is drawn.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram.  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{two red})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{exactly one red})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{at least one yellow})\).

---

### 2) Two bags (independent)
Two bags contain marbles as follows:

| Bag | Black | Red |
|---|---:|---:|
| A | 4 | 6 |
| B | 5 | 3 |

Peter takes **one marble from Bag A**, then **one marble from Bag B**.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram.  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{A is red AND B is black})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{one red and one black})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{both marbles are the same colour})\).  
**(e)** Find \(P(\text{marble from Bag B is red})\).

---

### 3) 3 colours, without replacement (2 draws)
A bag contains:

| Colour | Green | Blue | Red |
|---|---:|---:|---:|
| Number of balls | 3 | 4 | 5 |

Two balls are drawn one after another, **without replacement**.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram.  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{both balls are the same colour})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{exactly one green is drawn})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{at least one blue is drawn})\).  
**(e)** Find \(P(\text{second ball is red})\).

---

### 4) Without replacement (2 draws)
A bag contains **5 white** and **7 black** counters. Two counters are taken one after another, **without replacement**.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram.  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{white then black})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{one of each colour})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{two black})\).  
**(e)** Find \(P(\text{at most one black})\).

---

### 5) Mixed replacement rule (2 draws)
A box contains **4 red** and **8 blue** balls. One ball is drawn at random.

- If the first ball is **red**, it is **not replaced**.  
- If the first ball is **blue**, it **is replaced**.

A second ball is then drawn.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram.  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{both balls are red})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{balls are of different colours})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{second ball is red})\).  
**(e)** Find \(P(\text{at least one blue is drawn})\).

---

### 6) Mixed replacement rule with 3 colours (2 draws)
A bag contains **3 pink**, **5 yellow**, **4 black** balls. One ball is drawn at random.

- If the first ball is **black**, it is **not replaced**.  
- Otherwise (pink or yellow), it **is replaced**.

A second ball is then drawn.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram.  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{second ball is black})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{at least one black ball is drawn})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{both balls are the same colour})\).

---

### 7) 3 draws, without replacement
A bag contains **5 green**, **4 yellow**, **3 red** balls. Three balls are drawn one after another, **without replacement**.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram (3 stages).  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{at least two green are drawn})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{exactly one yellow is drawn})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{all three balls are different colours})\).  
**(e)** Find \(P(\text{third ball is red})\).

---

### 8) 3 draws, with replacement
A bag contains **2 red** and **3 blue** balls. Three balls are drawn one after another, **with replacement**.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram (3 stages).  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{exactly two red are drawn})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{at least one red is drawn})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{all three are the same colour})\).

---

### 9) All-different vs two-same (3 draws, without replacement)
A bag contains **2 red**, **2 blue**, **2 green** balls. Three balls are drawn one after another, **without replacement**.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram (3 stages).  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{all three are different colours})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{exactly two are the same colour})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{at least one green is drawn})\).

---

### 10) Find an unknown number (2 draws, without replacement)
A bag contains **10 balls**, of which \(r\) are red and the rest are blue. Two balls are drawn one after another, **without replacement**.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram in terms of \(r\).  
**(b)** Given that \(P(\text{both balls are red})=\dfrac{1}{15}\), find \(r\).

---

### 11) Find an unknown number (mixed replacement rule)
A bag contains \(x\) red balls and **3 blue** balls. One ball is drawn at random.

- If the first ball is **red**, it is **replaced**.  
- If the first ball is **blue**, it is **not replaced**.

A second ball is then drawn.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram in terms of \(x\).  
**(b)** Given that \(P(\text{second ball is red})=\dfrac{11}{20}\), find \(x\).

---

### 12) Third draw extension (without replacement)
A bag contains **5 blue** and **3 yellow** balls. Three balls are drawn one after another, **without replacement**.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram (3 stages).  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{first two balls are blue})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{at most one blue in the first two draws})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{at least two blue balls in three draws})\).

---

## Very concise answers

1. **(b)** \( \frac{25}{64} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{15}{32} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{39}{64} \)

2. **(b)** \( \frac{3}{8} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{21}{40} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{19}{40} \)  **(e)** \( \frac{3}{8} \)

3. **(b)** \( \frac{19}{66} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{9}{22} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{19}{33} \)  **(e)** \( \frac{5}{12} \)

4. **(b)** \( \frac{35}{132} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{35}{66} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{7}{22} \)  **(e)** \( \frac{15}{22} \)

5. **(b)** \( \frac{1}{11} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{46}{99} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{31}{99} \)  **(e)** \( \frac{10}{11} \)

6. **(b)** \( \frac{31}{99} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{5}{9} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{259}{792} \)

7. **(b)** \( \frac{4}{11} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{28}{55} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{3}{11} \)  **(e)** \( \frac{1}{4} \)

8. **(b)** \( \frac{36}{125} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{98}{125} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{7}{25} \)

9. **(b)** \( \frac{2}{5} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{3}{5} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{4}{5} \)

10. **(b)** \( r=3 \)

11. **(b)** \( x=3 \)

12. **(b)** \( \frac{5}{14} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{9}{14} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{5}{7} \)

Devise 8 questions based on Part 3 and Part 5 of the attached lecture notes. 

- Target Difficulty level: Hard/Very difficult 
- Whilst you should adhere to the same style and pedagogy of the questions in Part 3 and Part 5, your questions should be original, some of the should involve high school algebra, and most should involve higher order reasoning.  
- Do NOT use the Bayes Theorem, Law of total probabiity or any concept beyond what is presented explicitly in the lecture notes examples and question. Do NOT say the words "conditional probability" even if your probability tree questions implicitly involves that concept (in 2nd stage branches onwards)
- Do not draw diagrams in your questions, but include tables where relevant. 
- For questions involving probability trees, ask the student to draw the full tree. Do not include any part of the tree in your question. Focus solely on describing in words the problem to be solved.

Include very concise answers. You can leave out all diagrams including trees in your answer, even if you had asked students to draw trees.

[L89] Part 3: Evaluating Probability (with or w/o diagrams)
[L90] Mutually Exclusive Events
[L91] Two outcomes/events are mutually exclusive if they cannot both occur at the same time.
[L92] For example, when we throw a dice, the outcome of obtaining a “1” and the outcome of obtaining 
[L93] a “6” are mutually exclusive because we cannot obtain both "1" and "6" at the same time.
[L94] Independent VS Dependent Events
[L95] Independent events are best illustrated in events where the object is replaced after picking.
[L96] Because the object is replaced, the probability of picking a second object will not be affected by 
[L97] the first pick.
[L98] Dependent events are best illustrated in events where the object is not replaced after picking.
[L99] As the object is not replaced, the probability of picking a second object will be affected by what 
[L100] was picked in the first pick.
[L101] Hence, for dependent events (i.e. events without replacement), we have to account and adjust for 
[L102] the object removed in the first pick before multiplying the probabilities.
[L103] Example of independent events
[L104] Two balls are randomly taken out, with replacement, from a bag of 3 red and 4 blue balls. Find the probability 
[L105] of taking out two blue balls.
[L106] 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵, 𝐵𝐵) = 4
[L107] 7
[L108] ×
[L109] 4
[L110] 7 = 16
[L111] 49
[L112] The probability of drawing the second blue ball �
[L113] 4
[L114] 7
[L115] � is same as the first blue ball �
[L116] 4
[L117] 7
[L118] �. 
[L119] The probability of the second event is unaffected by the first event. These are independent events
[L120] Example of dependent events
[L121] Two balls are randomly taken out, without replacement, from a bag of 3 red and 4 blue balls. Find the 
[L122] probability of taking out two blue balls.
[L123] 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵, 𝐵𝐵) = 4
[L124] 7
[L125] ×
[L126] 3
[L127] 6 = 2
[L128] 7
[L129] The probability of drawing the second blue ball �
[L130] 3
[L131] 6
[L132] � is different from the first blue ball �
[L133] 4
[L134] 7
[L135] �.

[L396] Part 2: Probability Tree Diagram
[L397] A Tree Diagram is a tool used to systematically displaying all the possible outcomes of a
[L398] combined event. It is a useful visual representation of the scenario and allows us to keep track 
[L399] of each probability and hence reduce error in calculation.
[L400] It is especially useful for dependent events where the subsequent event is affected by the 
[L401] occurrences of the first event.
[L402] Example:
[L403] A bag contains 3 blue token and 5 red tokens. Two tokens are taken out at random from the bag, one at 
[L404] a time, without replacement. Find the probability that 
[L405] a) both tokens are blue
[L406] b) one token is blue, one token is red
[L407] a) 𝑃𝑃( 𝑏𝑏ℎ 𝑡𝑡 𝑎𝑎 𝑏𝑏 ) = 3

[L427] Evaluate Probabilities at the end of a tree line
[L428] To find the probability of an outcome, multiply the probability along the tree branches for this

[L430] Evaluate Probabilities of several tree lines
[L431] To find the probability of several possible outcomes, add the probability of the different outcomes 
[L432] for the different branches.

[L750] Part 3: Evaluating Probability (with or w/o diagrams)
[L751] Mutually Exclusive Events
[L752] Two outcomes/events are mutually exclusive if they cannot both occur at the same time.
[L753] For example, when we throw a dice, the outcome of obtaining a “1” and the outcome of obtaining 
[L754] a “6” are mutually exclusive because we cannot obtain both "1" and "6" at the same time.
[L755] Independent VS Dependent Events
[L756] Independent events are best illustrated in events where the object is replaced after picking.
[L757] Because the object is replaced, the probability of picking a second object will not be affected by 
[L758] the first pick.
[L759] Dependent events are best illustrated in events where the object is not replaced after picking.
[L760] As the object is not replaced, the probability of picking a second object will be affected by what 
[L761] was picked in the first pick.
[L762] Hence, for dependent events (i.e. events without replacement), we have to account and adjust for 
[L763] the object removed in the first pick before multiplying the probabilities.
[L764] Example of independent events
[L765] Two balls are randomly taken out, with replacement, from a bag of 3 red and 4 blue balls. Find the probability 
[L766] of taking out two blue balls.
[L767] 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵, 𝐵𝐵) = 4
[L768] 7

[L770] 4
[L771] 7 = 16

[L774] 4

[L779] �. 
[L780] The probability of the second event is unaffected by the first event. These are independent events
[L781] Example of dependent events

[L801] Addition Law of Probabilities
[L802] 𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴 𝒐𝒐𝒐𝒐 𝐵𝐵) = 𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴) + 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵)
[L803] For example:
[L804] 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1 6 𝑎𝑎 ℎ ) = 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1) + 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 6)
[L805] = 1
[L806] 6
[L807] + 1
[L808] 6
[L809]  
[L810] = 1
[L811] 3
[L812] In short, the word “or” is associated with “+” when handling probabilities.
[L813] However, the two events/outcomes 𝐴𝐴 and 𝐵𝐵 must be mutually exclusive for this law to be true.
[L814] Multiplication Law of Probabilities
[L815] 𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴 𝐵𝐵) = 𝑃𝑃(𝐴𝐴) × 𝑃𝑃(𝐵𝐵)
[L816] For example: 
[L817] 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1 𝑚𝑚 𝑓𝑓 ℎ 𝑎𝑎 𝑎𝑎 𝑎𝑎 6 𝑚𝑚 ℎ )
[L818] = 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 1 𝑓𝑓 ℎ ) × 𝑃𝑃( 𝑜𝑜 6 ℎ )
[L819] = 1
[L820] 6
[L821] ×
[L822] 1
[L823] 6
[L824]  
[L825] = 1
[L826] 36
[L827] In short, the word “and” is associated with “×” (multiplication) when handling probabilities.
[L828] However, the two events/outcomes 𝐴𝐴 and 𝐵𝐵 must be independent for this law to be true.

[L1084] Worked Example 8
[L1085] A bag contains 8 buttons, 𝑛𝑛 of which are white and the rest are black. A button is chosen at 
[L1086] random and not replaced.
[L1087] a) Write down, in terms of n, the probability that the button is black.
[L1088] A second button is chosen at random.
[L1089] b) Find, in terms of 𝑛𝑛, the probability that both buttons are black.
[L1090] c) (i) The probability that both buttons are black is 3
[L1091] 28. 
[L1092] Show that 𝑛𝑛2 − 15𝑛𝑛 + 50 = 0
[L1093] (ii) Solve the equation 𝑛𝑛2 − 15𝑛𝑛 + 50 = 0 to find the number of black buttons in 
[L1094] the bag.
[L1095] Solution
[L1096] a) 8−𝑛𝑛
[L1097] 8
[L1098] b) 8−𝑛𝑛
[L1099] 8
[L1100] ×
[L1101] 8−𝑛𝑛−1
[L1102] 7
[L1103]  = 8−𝑛𝑛
[L1104] 8
[L1105] ×
[L1106] 7−𝑛𝑛
[L1107] 7
[L1108] c) 8−𝑛𝑛
[L1109] 8
[L1110] ×
[L1111] 7−𝑛𝑛
[L1112] 7 = 3
[L1113] 28
[L1114]  (8 − 𝑛𝑛)(7 − 𝑛𝑛) = 6
[L1115]  𝑛𝑛2 − 15𝑛𝑛 + 56 = 6
[L1116]  𝑛𝑛2 − 15𝑛𝑛 + 50 = 0
[L1117] d) 𝑛𝑛2 − 15𝑛𝑛 + 50 = 0
[L1118]  (𝑛𝑛 − 5)(𝑛𝑛 − 10) = 0
[L1119]  𝑛𝑛 − 5 = 0 or 𝑛𝑛 − 10 = 0
[L1120]  𝑛𝑛 = 5 or 𝑛𝑛 = 10
[L1121]  Since there are only 8 buttons, 𝑛𝑛 ≠ 10 and 𝑛𝑛 = 5
[L1122]  8 − 5 = 3
[L1123]  There are 3 black buttons in the bag

parts:
Based on **Part 3: Evaluating Probability (with or w/o diagrams)** and **Part 5: More Probability Questions (Intermediate/Advanced)** in the attached notes. fileciteturn5file0L748-L828 fileciteturn5file0L1599-L1661

## 8 Questions (Hard / Very Difficult)

### 1) Travel choice + late / not late (tree + repeated days)
Each morning, Zara travels by **Taxi**, **Bus** or **MRT**.

| Mode | Taxi | Bus | MRT |
|---|---:|---:|---:|
| Probability she uses this mode | \( \frac{3}{10} \) | \( \frac{2}{5} \) | \( \frac{3}{10} \) |
| Probability she is late (if she uses this mode) | \( \frac{1}{20} \) | \( \frac{1}{5} \) | \( \frac{1}{10} \) |

Assume each day behaves the same way and is unaffected by previous days.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram for one morning.  
**(b)** Find the probability Zara is late on a particular morning.  
**(c)** Over two consecutive mornings, find the probability she is late on **exactly one** day.  
**(d)** Over three consecutive mornings, find the probability she is on time on **at least one** day.  
**(e)** From Monday to Friday, find the probability she takes the **Bus** on all 5 days.

---

### 2) Three boxes: good vs bad (no tree needed)
One fruit is selected from each box:

| Box | Total | Bad | Good |
|---|---:|---:|---:|
| A | 10 | 2 | 8 |
| B | 8 | 2 | 6 |
| C | 6 | 1 | 5 |

**(a)** Find \(P(\text{all three are good})\).  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{exactly one is bad})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{at least one is bad})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{either all good OR all bad})\).  
**(e)** Find \(P(\text{at least two are good})\).

---

### 3) Algebra with two draws (quadratic)
A box contains **12 beads**. \(n\) are **white** and the rest are **black**. Two beads are chosen at random, **without replacement**.

You are told:
- The probability that the two beads are of **different colours** is \( \frac{9}{22} \).
- There are **more black beads than white beads**.

**(a)** Find \(n\).  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{both beads are black})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{at least one bead is white})\).

---

### 4) Three draws from 3 colours (tree)
A bag contains:

| Colour | Red | Blue | Green |
|---|---:|---:|---:|
| Number of balls | 5 | 4 | 3 |

Three balls are drawn one after another, **without replacement**.

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram (3 stages).  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{at least two red balls are drawn})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{exactly one green ball is drawn})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{all three balls are different colours})\).  
**(e)** Find \(P(\text{the first two balls are the same colour, and the third is different})\).

---

### 5) Maze in words (tree + algebra)
Allyson starts at junction **A**. At **every** junction, she either:
- goes **straight** with probability \( \frac{p}{7} \), where \(p\) is an integer from 1 to 6, or
- **changes direction** with probability \( \frac{7-p}{7} \).

Once she passes a junction, she cannot turn back. The game ends when she reaches a checkpoint or a dead end.

The maze behaves like this:
- At **A**: straight \(\to\) **B**; change direction \(\to\) **C**  
- At **B**: straight \(\to\) checkpoint **Y** (no prize); change direction \(\to\) **D**  
- At **C**: straight \(\to\) **D**; change direction \(\to\) checkpoint **Z** (no prize)  
- At **D**: straight \(\to\) checkpoint **X** (prize); change direction \(\to\) **Dead End**

**(a)** Draw the **full** probability tree diagram.  
**(b)** Write \(P(\text{wins prize at X})\) in terms of \(p\).  
**(c)** Given that \(P(\text{wins prize at X})=\frac{72}{343}\), find \(p\).  
**(d)** Hence find \(P(\text{hits the Dead End})\).  
**(e)** Hence find \(P(\text{ends at Y})\) and \(P(\text{ends at Z})\).

---

### 6) Target by area + total score
A target consists of 3 concentric circles with radii **1 cm**, **3 cm**, **5 cm**.

- Region **A**: inside radius 1 cm, score **60**  
- Region **B**: ring between 1 cm and 3 cm, score **20**  
- Region **C**: ring between 3 cm and 5 cm, score **5**

A shooter hits the target every time and is equally likely to hit any part of the target. Shots are independent.

**(a)** After 3 shots, find \(P(\text{total score }=85)\).  
**(b)** After 3 shots, find \(P(\text{total score }\ge 120)\).  
**(c)** After 2 shots, find \(P(\text{total score }\ge 80)\).

---

### 7) Product table + die (higher-order reasoning)
There are two bags:

| Bag P cards | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| Bag Q cards | 1 | 2 | 3 | 5 |

A card is drawn from each bag. Let \(a\) be the **product**.

**(a)** Copy and complete the probability diagram for \(a\).

| \(P \backslash Q\) | 1 | 2 | 3 | 5 |
|---|---:|---:|---:|---:|
| 1 |  |  |  |  |
| 2 |  |  |  |  |
| 3 |  |  |  |  |
| 4 |  |  |  |  |

An unbiased die has faces: \(2,4,7,9,11,14\). It is thrown once. Let the outcome be \(b\).

**(b)** Find \(P(a \text{ is prime})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(a+b \text{ is odd})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(a+b>15)\).  
**(e)** Find \(P(a+b \text{ is a multiple of }3)\).

---

### 8) City blood types (large population)
A city has blood types as follows:

| Type | O | A | B | AB |
|---|---:|---:|---:|---:|
| Percentage | 45% | 40% | 11% | 4% |

Three people are selected at random. Assume the city is so large that these percentages remain effectively unchanged from one selection to the next.

**(a)** Find \(P(\text{at least one person is type AB})\).  
**(b)** Find \(P(\text{exactly one person is type O})\).  
**(c)** Find \(P(\text{at least two people are type O})\).  
**(d)** Find \(P(\text{all three have different blood types})\).

---

## Very concise answers

1. **(b)** \( \frac{1}{8} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{7}{32} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{511}{512} \)  **(e)** \( \frac{32}{3125} \)

2. **(a)** \( \frac{1}{2} \)  **(b)** \( \frac{47}{120} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{1}{2} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{61}{120} \)  **(e)** \( \frac{107}{120} \)

3. **(a)** \(n=3\)  **(b)** \( \frac{6}{11} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{5}{11} \)

4. **(b)** \( \frac{4}{11} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{27}{55} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{3}{11} \)  **(e)** \( \frac{29}{132} \)

5. **(b)** \( \dfrac{2p^2(7-p)}{343} \)  **(c)** \(p=3\)  **(d)** \( \frac{96}{343} \)  **(e)** \(P(Y)=\frac{9}{49},\; P(Z)=\frac{16}{49}\)

6. **(a)** \( \frac{768}{15625} \)  **(b)** \( \frac{73}{15625} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{17}{625} \)

7. **(a)**  
| \(P \backslash Q\) | 1 | 2 | 3 | 5 |
|---|---:|---:|---:|---:|
| 1 | 1 | 2 | 3 | 5 |
| 2 | 2 | 4 | 6 | 10 |
| 3 | 3 | 6 | 9 | 15 |
| 4 | 4 | 8 | 12 | 20 |

**(b)** \( \frac{5}{16} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{1}{2} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{5}{12} \)  **(e)** \( \frac{29}{96} \)

8. **(a)** \( \frac{1801}{15625} \)  **(b)** \( \frac{3267}{8000} \)  **(c)** \( \frac{1701}{4000} \)  **(d)** \( \frac{4611}{25000} \)

content.text:
from collections import Counter
def exactly_two_same(t):
    counts=Counter(t).values()
    return sorted(counts)==[1,2]
def ap_all_diff(t):
    # all different and can be arranged to form AP
    if len(set(t))!=3: 
        return False
    s=sorted(t)
    return s[1]-s[0]==s[2]-s[1]
prob=lambda cond: Fraction(sum(1 for t in out if cond(t)), len(out))
prob(exactly_two_same), prob(ap_all_diff)

import itertools
balls=['R']*5+['B']*4+['G']*3
# sequential draws without replacement: ordered outcomes equal among permutations of 12 choose 3? Actually order matters; total outcomes 12*11*10
out=[]
for i in range(len(balls)):
    for j in range(len(balls)):
        if j==i: continue
        for k in range(len(balls)):
            if k==i or k==j: continue
            out.append((balls[i], balls[j], balls[k]))
len(out)

from fractions import Fraction
pA=Fraction(1,25)
pB=Fraction(8,25)
pC=Fraction(16,25)
scores={'A':60,'B':20,'C':5}
probs={'A':pA,'B':pB,'C':pC}
# enumerate 3 shots
import itertools
tot=Fraction(0,1)
tot85=Fraction(0,1)
tot_ge120=Fraction(0,1)
for seq in itertools.product('ABC', repeat=3):
    p=Fraction(1,1)
    s=0
    for x in seq:
        p*=probs[x]; s+=scores[x]
    if s==85: tot85+=p
    if s>=120: tot_ge120+=p
tot85, tot_ge120

from fractions import Fraction
P=[1,2,3,4]
Q=[1,2,3,5]
a_out=[p*q for p in P for q in Q]  # 16 equally likely
b_faces=[2,4,7,9,11,14]
total=Fraction(0,1)
fav=Fraction(0,1)
fav_mult3=Fraction(0,1)
for a in a_out:
    for b in b_faces:
        prob=Fraction(1,16)*Fraction(1,6)
        if a+b>15:
            fav+=prob
        if (a+b)%3==0:
            fav_mult3+=prob
fav, fav_mult3

content.text:
from fractions import Fraction
pO=Fraction(45,100)
pA=Fraction(40,100)
pB=Fraction(11,100)
pAB=Fraction(4,100)
# (a)
a=1-(1-pAB)**3
# (b) exactly one O
b=3*pO*(1-pO)**2
# (c) at least two O
c=3*pO**2*(1-pO)+pO**3
# (d) all three different types
# compute sum over permutations of 3 distinct types
types=[pO,pA,pB,pAB]
import itertools
d=Fraction(0,1)
labels=['O','A','B','AB']
prob_map={'O':pO,'A':pA,'B':pB,'AB':pAB}
for comb_labels in itertools.combinations(labels,3):
    # sum over 3! permutations
    probs=[prob_map[l] for l in comb_labels]
    prod=probs[0]*probs[1]*probs[2]
    d += 6*prod
a,b,c,d

```latex
\documentclass[11pt]{article}

\usepackage[margin=1in]{geometry}
\usepackage{amsmath,amssymb}
\usepackage{array,booktabs}
\usepackage{enumitem}
\usepackage{multicol}
\usepackage{graphicx}

\setlist[itemize]{leftmargin=*}
\setlist[enumerate]{leftmargin=*}

\begin{document}

\section*{Part 1}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]

\item \textbf{Cards (Sum, without replacement)}\\
A box contains 5 identical cards numbered $1,2,4,7,8$. Two cards are drawn at random, one after another, \textbf{without replacement}. The \textbf{sum} is recorded.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Copy and complete the possibility diagram (write \textbf{X} on the diagonal).
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
1st $\backslash$ 2nd & 1 & 2 & 4 & 7 & 8\\
\hline
1 & X &  &  &  & \\
\hline
2 &  & X &  &  & \\
\hline
4 &  &  & X &  & \\
\hline
7 &  &  &  & X & \\
\hline
8 &  &  &  &  & X\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\item Find $P(\text{sum}=9)$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum is prime})$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum}\ge 10)$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum is even})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Dice (Union of events)}\\
Two unbiased six-sided dice are thrown.\\
Let $A$: ``sum is a \textbf{prime} number''.\\
Let $B$: ``difference (larger$-$smaller) is $2$''.\\
Find $P(A)$, $P(B)$, $P(A\cap B)$, $P(A\cup B)$.

\item \textbf{Balls (Product + ``at least'' via complement)}\\
A bag contains 5 balls numbered $1,2,4,5,9$. Two balls are drawn, one after another, \textbf{without replacement}. The \textbf{product} is recorded.\\
Find the probability that the product is
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item a perfect square,
\item a multiple of $10$,
\item greater than $20$,
\item \textbf{at least one} ball drawn is numbered $9$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Two spinners (Sum table)}\\
Spinner $P$ has outcomes $2,4,6,8$ (equally likely).\\
Spinner $Q$ has outcomes $1,3,5$ (equally likely).\\
Each spinner is spun once. The \textbf{sum} is recorded.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Complete the possibility diagram.
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
$P\backslash Q$ & 1 & 3 & 5\\
\hline
2 &  &  & \\
\hline
4 &  &  & \\
\hline
6 &  &  & \\
\hline
8 &  &  & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\item Find $P(\text{sum is prime})$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum is a multiple of }3)$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum} > 10)$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum is odd})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Cards (Difference table, without replacement)}\\
A box contains 4 cards numbered $1,3,4,6$. Two cards are drawn, one after another, \textbf{without replacement}. The \textbf{difference} (larger$-$smaller) is recorded.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Complete the possibility diagram (write \textbf{X} on the diagonal).
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
1st $\backslash$ 2nd & 1 & 3 & 4 & 6\\
\hline
1 & X &  &  & \\
\hline
3 &  & X &  & \\
\hline
4 &  &  & X & \\
\hline
6 &  &  &  & X\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\item Find $P(\text{difference}=1)$.
\item Find $P(\text{difference is prime})$.
\item Find $P(\text{difference}\le 2)$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Coloured balls (Mixed colours, without replacement)}\\
A bag contains 2 red, 3 blue, and 1 green ball. Two balls are drawn, one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.\\
Find the probability that
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item both balls are blue,
\item the two balls are different colours,
\item at most one blue ball is drawn,
\item at least one green ball is drawn.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{With vs without replacement (compare probabilities)}\\
A box contains 4 cards numbered $1,2,4,7$. Two cards are drawn.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Without replacement, find $P(\text{sum} > 8)$.
\item With replacement, find $P(\text{sum} > 8)$.
\item A student says (b) must be larger because ``there are more favourable outcomes''. Is the student correct?
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Dice (Product properties)}\\
Two unbiased six-sided dice are thrown.\\
Find the probability that the \textbf{product} is
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item $12$,
\item a multiple of $5$,
\item a perfect square.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Two-digit number from digits (without replacement)}\\
Cards numbered $1$ to $9$ are placed in a bag. Two cards are drawn, one after another, \textbf{without replacement}, and a \textbf{two-digit number} is formed (first draw = tens digit).\\
Find the probability that the number is
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item divisible by $4$,
\item divisible by $3$ \textbf{or} $5$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Three dice (counting)}\\
Three unbiased six-sided dice are thrown.\\
Find the probability that
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item exactly two dice show the same number,
\item all three numbers are different and can be arranged to form an arithmetic progression.
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

\section*{Part 2}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]

\item \textbf{With replacement (2 draws)}\\
A bag contains the following balls:
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
Colour & Red & Yellow\\
\hline
Number of balls & 5 & 3\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
A ball is drawn at random, \textbf{replaced}, then a second ball is drawn.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Find $P(\text{two red})$.
\item Find $P(\text{exactly one red})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one yellow})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Two bags (independent)}\\
Two bags contain marbles as follows:

\hline
B & 5 & 3\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
Peter takes one marble from Bag A, then one marble from Bag B.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]

\item Find $P(\text{A is red AND B is black})$.
\item Find $P(\text{one red and one black})$.
\item Find $P(\text{both marbles are the same colour})$.
\item Find $P(\text{marble from Bag B is red})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{3 colours, without replacement (2 draws)}\\
A bag contains:
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Colour & Green & Blue & Red\\
\hline
Number of balls & 3 & 4 & 5\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
Two balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Find $P(\text{both balls are the same colour})$.
\item Find $P(\text{exactly one green is drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one blue is drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{second ball is red})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Without replacement (2 draws)}\\
A bag contains 5 white and 7 black counters. Two counters are taken one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]

\item Find $P(\text{white then black})$.
\item Find $P(\text{one of each colour})$.
\item Find $P(\text{two black})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at most one black})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Mixed replacement rule (2 draws)}\\
A box contains 4 red and 8 blue balls. One ball is drawn at random.
\begin{itemize}
\item If the first ball is \textbf{red}, it is \textbf{not replaced}.
\item If the first ball is \textbf{blue}, it \textbf{is replaced}.
\end{itemize}
A second ball is then drawn.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Find $P(\text{both balls are red})$.
\item Find $P(\text{balls are of different colours})$.
\item Find $P(\text{second ball is red})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one blue is drawn})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Mixed replacement rule with 3 colours (2 draws)}\\
A bag contains 3 pink, 5 yellow, 4 black balls. One ball is drawn at random.
\begin{itemize}

\item Otherwise (pink or yellow), it \textbf{is replaced}.
\end{itemize}
A second ball is then drawn.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Find $P(\text{second ball is black})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one black ball is drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{both balls are the same colour})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{3 draws, without replacement}\\
A bag contains 5 green, 4 yellow, 3 red balls. Three balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.

\item Find $P(\text{at least two green are drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{exactly one yellow is drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{all three balls are different colours})$.
\item Find $P(\text{third ball is red})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{3 draws, with replacement}\\

\item Find $P(\text{all three are the same colour})$.

\item \textbf{All-different vs two-same (3 draws, without replacement)}\\

\item Find $P(\text{exactly two are the same colour})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one green is drawn})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Find an unknown number (2 draws, without replacement)}\\
A bag contains 10 balls, of which $r$ are red and the rest are blue. Two balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.

\item Given that $P(\text{both balls are red})=\dfrac{1}{15}$, find $r$.

\item \textbf{Find an unknown number (mixed replacement rule)}\\

\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram in terms of $x$.

\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Third draw extension (without replacement)}\\
A bag contains 5 blue and 3 yellow balls. Three balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]

\item Find $P(\text{at most one blue in the first two draws})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least two blue balls in three draws})$.
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]

\item \textbf{Travel choice + late / not late (tree + repeated days)}\\

\hline

\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]

\item Over three consecutive mornings, find the probability she is on time on \textbf{at least one} day.
\item From Monday to Friday, find the probability she takes the Bus on all 5 days.

\item \textbf{Algebra with two draws (quadratic)}\\

\item There are \textbf{more black beads than white beads}.
\end{itemize}

\item Find $P(\text{both beads are black})$.

\end{center}
Three balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.

\item Find $P(\text{all three balls are different colours})$.
\item Find $P(\text{the first two balls are the same colour, and the third is different})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Maze in words (tree + algebra)}\\
Allyson starts at junction A. At \textbf{every} junction, she either:
\begin{itemize}
\item goes straight with probability $\dfrac{p}{7}$, where $p$ is an integer from 1 to 6, or
\item changes direction with probability $\dfrac{7-p}{7}$.
\end{itemize}
Once she passes a junction, she cannot turn back. The game ends when she reaches a checkpoint or a dead end.\\[0.25em]
The maze behaves like this:
\begin{itemize}
\item At A: straight $\to$ B; change direction $\to$ C
\item At B: straight $\to$ checkpoint Y (no prize); change direction $\to$ D
\item At C: straight $\to$ D; change direction $\to$ checkpoint Z (no prize)
\item At D: straight $\to$ checkpoint X (prize); change direction $\to$ Dead End
\end{itemize}
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Write $P(\text{wins prize at X})$ in terms of $p$.
\item Given that $P(\text{wins prize at X})=\dfrac{72}{343}$, find $p$.
\item Hence find $P(\text{hits the Dead End})$.
\item Hence find $P(\text{ends at Y})$ and $P(\text{ends at Z})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item Region C: ring between 3 cm and 5 cm, score 5
\end{itemize}
A shooter hits the target every time and is equally likely to hit any part of the target. Shots are independent.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item After 3 shots, find $P(\text{total score }=85)$.
\item After 3 shots, find $P(\text{total score }\ge 120)$.
\item After 2 shots, find $P(\text{total score }\ge 80)$.
\end{enumerate}

\end{center}

$P\backslash Q$ & 1 & 2 & 3 & 5\\

1 &  &  &  & \\

\end{tabular}
\end{center}
An unbiased die has faces: $2,4,7,9,11,14$. It is thrown once. Let the outcome be $b$.
\item Find $P(a \text{ is prime})$.

\item \textbf{City blood types (large population)}\\
A city has blood types as follows:

Type & O & A & B & AB\\
\hline
Percentage & 45\% & 40\% & 11\% & 4\%\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
Three people are selected at random. Assume the city is so large that these percentages remain effectively unchanged from one selection to the next.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Find $P(\text{at least one person is type AB})$.
\item Find $P(\text{exactly one person is type O})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least two people are type O})$.
\item Find $P(\text{all three have different blood types})$.
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}
```

thoughts.summary: Fixing LaTeX for table resizing in double column
thoughts.content: To fix the overspill issue, it's possible that the \resizebox{\columnwidth}{!} isn't factoring in the center environment within multicol. Try removing the \center environment or ensuring the table's width is explicitly defined within it. Also, ensure \columnwidth is consistent with the space allocated in multicol. This might solve the problem.

thoughts.summary: Fixing LaTeX for table resizing in multicol
thoughts.content: The issue might be that inside multicol, \resizebox uses \columnwidth, but it could be referencing the full text width, not column width. To fix this, it’s safer to use \linewidth to match the column width. Another option is to adjust table spacing with \begin{center}, \small, and \scriptsize.

To fix this, it’s safer to use \linewidth to match the column width.
Another option is to adjust table spacing with \begin{center}, \small, and \scriptsize.

thoughts.summary: Updated LaTeX for table resizing and float management
thoughts.content: To fix the overspill issue, replace \resizebox{\columnwidth}{!}{...} with \resizebox{\linewidth}{!}. Also, inside a group, use \setlength{\tabcolsep}{2pt} and \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{0.9} to control table spacing. Consider using a macro for table formatting, like \newcommand{\answertable}[1]{\begingroup\setlength{\tabcolsep}{2pt}...\endgroup}. The tabular environment should work without floating.

thoughts.summary: Fixing LaTeX table overspill in multicol
thoughts.content: To avoid table overspill, we can define a new environment \coltable{}. This will include settings like \setlength{\tabcolsep}{2pt} for spacing, \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{0.9}, and \resizebox{\linewidth}{!} for scaling the table to column width. You can use \coltable{\begin{tabular}...} to apply this setup and prevent overspill.

for scaling the table to column width.
You can use \coltable{\begin{tabular}...}
to apply this setup and prevent overspill.

parts:
Yep — that overspill usually happens because inside `multicols`, **`\columnwidth` isn’t reliably the column width**, while **`\linewidth` is**. So your `\resizebox{\columnwidth}{!}{...}` can end up scaling to (almost) the full page width and bleed into the neighbouring column.

### Fix (clean + reusable)
1) **Add this helper macro** to your preamble (after `\usepackage{graphicx}`):

```latex
% Fit tables to the current column (works correctly inside multicols)
\newcommand{\ColFitTable}[1]{%
  \begin{center}
    \setlength{\tabcolsep}{2pt}%
    \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{0.9}%
    \scriptsize
    \resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{#1}%
  \end{center}
}
```

2) **Replace every answer-table block** of the form:

```latex
\begin{center}
\resizebox{\columnwidth}{!}{%
\begin{tabular}{...}
...
\end{tabular}}
\end{center}
```

with:

```latex
\ColFitTable{%
\begin{tabular}{...}
...
\end{tabular}}
```

---

## Drop-in replacements for your 4 answer tables

### Part 1 Q1 (6 columns)
Replace that whole table chunk with:

```latex
\hline

\hline
2 & 3 & X & 6 & 9 & 10\\
\hline
4 & 5 & 6 & X & 11 & 12\\
\hline

\hline
8 & 9 & 10 & 12 & 15 & X\\
\hline
\end{tabular}}
```

### Part 1 Q4 (4 columns)
```latex

\hline
$P\backslash Q$ & 1 & 3 & 5\\
\hline
2 & 3 & 5 & 7\\
\hline
4 & 5 & 7 & 9\\
\hline
6 & 7 & 9 & 11\\
\hline
8 & 9 & 11 & 13\\
\hline
\end{tabular}}
```

### Part 1 Q5 (5 columns)
```latex
\ColFitTable{%

\hline
1st $\backslash$ 2nd & 1 & 3 & 4 & 6\\
\hline
1 & X & 2 & 3 & 5\\
\hline
3 & 2 & X & 1 & 3\\
\hline
4 & 3 & 1 & X & 2\\
\hline
6 & 5 & 3 & 2 & X\\
\hline
\end{tabular}}
```

### Part 3 Q7 (5 columns)
```latex

\hline

\hline

\hline

\hline

\hline

```

### If you *still* see tight spacing
Change the macro’s `tabcolsep` from `2pt` to `1.5pt` (or `1pt`) and/or drop `\scriptsize` to `\tiny`.

If you want, paste the exact LaTeX error/output snippet you’re seeing (or a screenshot of the overspill), and I’ll tune the macro to your compiler/settings.
Can you output the entire latex again with your suggested modifications?

parts:
```latex
\documentclass[11pt]{article}

\usepackage[margin=1in]{geometry}
\usepackage{amsmath,amssymb}
\usepackage{array,booktabs}
\usepackage{enumitem}
\usepackage{multicol}
\usepackage{graphicx}

\setlist[itemize]{leftmargin=*}
\setlist[enumerate]{leftmargin=*}

% Fit tables to the current column (works correctly inside multicols)
\newcommand{\ColFitTable}[1]{%
  \begin{center}
    {\setlength{\tabcolsep}{2pt}%
     \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{0.9}%
     \scriptsize
     \resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{#1}}%
  \end{center}
}

\begin{document}

\section*{Part 1}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]

\item \textbf{Cards (Sum, without replacement)}\\
A box contains 5 identical cards numbered $1,2,4,7,8$. Two cards are drawn at random, one after another, \textbf{without replacement}. The \textbf{sum} is recorded.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Copy and complete the possibility diagram (write \textbf{X} on the diagonal).
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
1st $\backslash$ 2nd & 1 & 2 & 4 & 7 & 8\\
\hline
1 & X &  &  &  & \\
\hline
2 &  & X &  &  & \\
\hline
4 &  &  & X &  & \\
\hline
7 &  &  &  & X & \\
\hline
8 &  &  &  &  & X\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\item Find $P(\text{sum}=9)$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum is prime})$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum}\ge 10)$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum is even})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Dice (Union of events)}\\
Two unbiased six-sided dice are thrown.\\
Let $A$: ``sum is a \textbf{prime} number''.\\
Let $B$: ``difference (larger$-$smaller) is $2$''.\\
Find $P(A)$, $P(B)$, $P(A\cap B)$, $P(A\cup B)$.

\item \textbf{Balls (Product + ``at least'' via complement)}\\
A bag contains 5 balls numbered $1,2,4,5,9$. Two balls are drawn, one after another, \textbf{without replacement}. The \textbf{product} is recorded.\\
Find the probability that the product is
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item a perfect square,
\item a multiple of $10$,
\item greater than $20$,
\item \textbf{at least one} ball drawn is numbered $9$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Two spinners (Sum table)}\\
Spinner $P$ has outcomes $2,4,6,8$ (equally likely).\\
Spinner $Q$ has outcomes $1,3,5$ (equally likely).\\
Each spinner is spun once. The \textbf{sum} is recorded.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Complete the possibility diagram.
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
$P\backslash Q$ & 1 & 3 & 5\\
\hline
2 &  &  & \\
\hline
4 &  &  & \\
\hline
6 &  &  & \\
\hline
8 &  &  & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\item Find $P(\text{sum is prime})$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum is a multiple of }3)$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum} > 10)$.
\item Find $P(\text{sum is odd})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Cards (Difference table, without replacement)}\\
A box contains 4 cards numbered $1,3,4,6$. Two cards are drawn, one after another, \textbf{without replacement}. The \textbf{difference} (larger$-$smaller) is recorded.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Complete the possibility diagram (write \textbf{X} on the diagonal).
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
1st $\backslash$ 2nd & 1 & 3 & 4 & 6\\
\hline
1 & X &  &  & \\
\hline
3 &  & X &  & \\
\hline
4 &  &  & X & \\
\hline
6 &  &  &  & X\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\item Find $P(\text{difference}=1)$.
\item Find $P(\text{difference is prime})$.
\item Find $P(\text{difference}\le 2)$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Coloured balls (Mixed colours, without replacement)}\\
A bag contains 2 red, 3 blue, and 1 green ball. Two balls are drawn, one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.\\
Find the probability that
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item both balls are blue,
\item the two balls are different colours,
\item at most one blue ball is drawn,
\item at least one green ball is drawn.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{With vs without replacement (compare probabilities)}\\
A box contains 4 cards numbered $1,2,4,7$. Two cards are drawn.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Without replacement, find $P(\text{sum} > 8)$.
\item With replacement, find $P(\text{sum} > 8)$.
\item A student says (b) must be larger because ``there are more favourable outcomes''. Is the student correct?
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Dice (Product properties)}\\
Two unbiased six-sided dice are thrown.\\
Find the probability that the \textbf{product} is
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item $12$,
\item a multiple of $5$,
\item a perfect square.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Two-digit number from digits (without replacement)}\\
Cards numbered $1$ to $9$ are placed in a bag. Two cards are drawn, one after another, \textbf{without replacement}, and a \textbf{two-digit number} is formed (first draw = tens digit).\\
Find the probability that the number is
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item divisible by $4$,
\item divisible by $3$ \textbf{or} $5$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Three dice (counting)}\\
Three unbiased six-sided dice are thrown.\\
Find the probability that
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item exactly two dice show the same number,
\item all three numbers are different and can be arranged to form an arithmetic progression.
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

\section*{Part 2}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]

\item \textbf{With replacement (2 draws)}\\
A bag contains the following balls:
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
Colour & Red & Yellow\\
\hline
Number of balls & 5 & 3\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
A ball is drawn at random, \textbf{replaced}, then a second ball is drawn.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Find $P(\text{two red})$.
\item Find $P(\text{exactly one red})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one yellow})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Two bags (independent)}\\
Two bags contain marbles as follows:
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
Bag & Black & Red\\
\hline
A & 4 & 6\\
\hline
B & 5 & 3\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
Peter takes one marble from Bag A, then one marble from Bag B.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Find $P(\text{A is red AND B is black})$.
\item Find $P(\text{one red and one black})$.
\item Find $P(\text{both marbles are the same colour})$.
\item Find $P(\text{marble from Bag B is red})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{3 colours, without replacement (2 draws)}\\
A bag contains:
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Colour & Green & Blue & Red\\
\hline
Number of balls & 3 & 4 & 5\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
Two balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Find $P(\text{both balls are the same colour})$.
\item Find $P(\text{exactly one green is drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one blue is drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{second ball is red})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Without replacement (2 draws)}\\
A bag contains 5 white and 7 black counters. Two counters are taken one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Find $P(\text{white then black})$.
\item Find $P(\text{one of each colour})$.
\item Find $P(\text{two black})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at most one black})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Mixed replacement rule (2 draws)}\\
A box contains 4 red and 8 blue balls. One ball is drawn at random.
\begin{itemize}
\item If the first ball is \textbf{red}, it is \textbf{not replaced}.
\item If the first ball is \textbf{blue}, it \textbf{is replaced}.
\end{itemize}
A second ball is then drawn.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Find $P(\text{both balls are red})$.
\item Find $P(\text{balls are of different colours})$.
\item Find $P(\text{second ball is red})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one blue is drawn})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Mixed replacement rule with 3 colours (2 draws)}\\
A bag contains 3 pink, 5 yellow, 4 black balls. One ball is drawn at random.
\begin{itemize}
\item If the first ball is \textbf{black}, it is \textbf{not replaced}.
\item Otherwise (pink or yellow), it \textbf{is replaced}.
\end{itemize}
A second ball is then drawn.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Find $P(\text{second ball is black})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one black ball is drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{both balls are the same colour})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{3 draws, without replacement}\\
A bag contains 5 green, 4 yellow, 3 red balls. Three balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram (3 stages).
\item Find $P(\text{at least two green are drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{exactly one yellow is drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{all three balls are different colours})$.
\item Find $P(\text{third ball is red})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{3 draws, with replacement}\\
A bag contains 2 red and 3 blue balls. Three balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{with replacement}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram (3 stages).
\item Find $P(\text{exactly two red are drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one red is drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{all three are the same colour})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{All-different vs two-same (3 draws, without replacement)}\\
A bag contains 2 red, 2 blue, 2 green balls. Three balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram (3 stages).
\item Find $P(\text{all three are different colours})$.
\item Find $P(\text{exactly two are the same colour})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one green is drawn})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Find an unknown number (2 draws, without replacement)}\\
A bag contains 10 balls, of which $r$ are red and the rest are blue. Two balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram in terms of $r$.
\item Given that $P(\text{both balls are red})=\dfrac{1}{15}$, find $r$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Find an unknown number (mixed replacement rule)}\\
A bag contains $x$ red balls and 3 blue balls. One ball is drawn at random.
\begin{itemize}
\item If the first ball is \textbf{red}, it is \textbf{replaced}.
\item If the first ball is \textbf{blue}, it is \textbf{not replaced}.
\end{itemize}
A second ball is then drawn.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram in terms of $x$.
\item Given that $P(\text{second ball is red})=\dfrac{11}{20}$, find $x$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Third draw extension (without replacement)}\\
A bag contains 5 blue and 3 yellow balls. Three balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram (3 stages).
\item Find $P(\text{first two balls are blue})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at most one blue in the first two draws})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least two blue balls in three draws})$.
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

\section*{Part 3}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]

\item \textbf{Travel choice + late / not late (tree + repeated days)}\\
Each morning, Zara travels by Taxi, Bus or MRT.
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Mode & Taxi & Bus & MRT\\
\hline
Probability she uses this mode & $\dfrac{3}{10}$ & $\dfrac{2}{5}$ & $\dfrac{3}{10}$\\
\hline
Probability she is late (if she uses this mode) & $\dfrac{1}{20}$ & $\dfrac{1}{5}$ & $\dfrac{1}{10}$\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
Assume each day behaves the same way and is unaffected by previous days.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram for one morning.
\item Find the probability Zara is late on a particular morning.
\item Over two consecutive mornings, find the probability she is late on \textbf{exactly one} day.
\item Over three consecutive mornings, find the probability she is on time on \textbf{at least one} day.
\item From Monday to Friday, find the probability she takes the Bus on all 5 days.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Three boxes: good vs bad (no tree needed)}\\
One fruit is selected from each box:
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Box & Total & Bad & Good\\
\hline
A & 10 & 2 & 8\\
\hline
B & 8 & 2 & 6\\
\hline
C & 6 & 1 & 5\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Find $P(\text{all three are good})$.
\item Find $P(\text{exactly one is bad})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one is bad})$.
\item Find $P(\text{either all good OR all bad})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least two are good})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Algebra with two draws (quadratic)}\\
A box contains 12 beads. $n$ are white and the rest are black. Two beads are chosen at random, \textbf{without replacement}.\\
You are told:
\begin{itemize}
\item The probability that the two beads are of \textbf{different colours} is $\dfrac{9}{22}$.
\item There are \textbf{more black beads than white beads}.
\end{itemize}
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Find $n$.
\item Find $P(\text{both beads are black})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least one bead is white})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Three draws from 3 colours (tree)}\\
A bag contains:
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Colour & Red & Blue & Green\\
\hline
Number of balls & 5 & 4 & 3\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
Three balls are drawn one after another, \textbf{without replacement}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram (3 stages).
\item Find $P(\text{at least two red balls are drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{exactly one green ball is drawn})$.
\item Find $P(\text{all three balls are different colours})$.
\item Find $P(\text{the first two balls are the same colour, and the third is different})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Maze in words (tree + algebra)}\\
Allyson starts at junction A. At \textbf{every} junction, she either:
\begin{itemize}
\item goes straight with probability $\dfrac{p}{7}$, where $p$ is an integer from 1 to 6, or
\item changes direction with probability $\dfrac{7-p}{7}$.
\end{itemize}
Once she passes a junction, she cannot turn back. The game ends when she reaches a checkpoint or a dead end.\\[0.25em]
The maze behaves like this:
\begin{itemize}
\item At A: straight $\to$ B; change direction $\to$ C
\item At B: straight $\to$ checkpoint Y (no prize); change direction $\to$ D
\item At C: straight $\to$ D; change direction $\to$ checkpoint Z (no prize)
\item At D: straight $\to$ checkpoint X (prize); change direction $\to$ Dead End
\end{itemize}
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Draw the \textbf{full} probability tree diagram.
\item Write $P(\text{wins prize at X})$ in terms of $p$.
\item Given that $P(\text{wins prize at X})=\dfrac{72}{343}$, find $p$.
\item Hence find $P(\text{hits the Dead End})$.
\item Hence find $P(\text{ends at Y})$ and $P(\text{ends at Z})$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Target by area + total score}\\
A target consists of 3 concentric circles with radii 1 cm, 3 cm, 5 cm.
\begin{itemize}
\item Region A: inside radius 1 cm, score 60
\item Region B: ring between 1 cm and 3 cm, score 20
\item Region C: ring between 3 cm and 5 cm, score 5
\end{itemize}
A shooter hits the target every time and is equally likely to hit any part of the target. Shots are independent.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item After 3 shots, find $P(\text{total score }=85)$.
\item After 3 shots, find $P(\text{total score }\ge 120)$.
\item After 2 shots, find $P(\text{total score }\ge 80)$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{Product table + die (higher-order reasoning)}\\
There are two bags:
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Bag P cards & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\qquad
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Bag Q cards & 1 & 2 & 3 & 5\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
A card is drawn from each bag. Let $a$ be the \textbf{product}.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Copy and complete the probability diagram for $a$.
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
$P\backslash Q$ & 1 & 2 & 3 & 5\\
\hline
1 &  &  &  & \\
\hline
2 &  &  &  & \\
\hline
3 &  &  &  & \\
\hline
4 &  &  &  & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
An unbiased die has faces: $2,4,7,9,11,14$. It is thrown once. Let the outcome be $b$.
\item Find $P(a \text{ is prime})$.
\item Find $P(a+b \text{ is odd})$.
\item Find $P(a+b>15)$.
\item Find $P(a+b \text{ is a multiple of }3)$.
\end{enumerate}

\item \textbf{City blood types (large population)}\\
A city has blood types as follows:
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Type & O & A & B & AB\\
\hline
Percentage & 45\% & 40\% & 11\% & 4\%\\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
Three people are selected at random. Assume the city is so large that these percentages remain effectively unchanged from one selection to the next.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Find $P(\text{at least one person is type AB})$.
\item Find $P(\text{exactly one person is type O})$.
\item Find $P(\text{at least two people are type O})$.
\item Find $P(\text{all three have different blood types})$.
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

\newpage
\section*{Answers}

\footnotesize
\begin{multicols}{2}

\textbf{Part 1}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\textbf{Q\arabic*.}]
\item (a)
\ColFitTable{%
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
1st $\backslash$ 2nd & 1 & 2 & 4 & 7 & 8\\
\hline
1 & X & 3 & 5 & 8 & 9\\
\hline
2 & 3 & X & 6 & 9 & 10\\
\hline
4 & 5 & 6 & X & 11 & 12\\
\hline
7 & 8 & 9 & 11 & X & 15\\
\hline
8 & 9 & 10 & 12 & 15 & X\\
\hline
\end{tabular}}
(b) $\frac{1}{5}$;\;
(c) $\frac{3}{10}$;\;
(d) $\frac{2}{5}$;\;
(e) $\frac{2}{5}$.

\item $P(A)=\frac{5}{12}$,\; $P(B)=\frac{2}{9}$,\; $P(A\cap B)=0$,\; $P(A\cup B)=\frac{23}{36}$.

\item (a) $\frac{3}{10}$;\;
(b) $\frac{1}{5}$;\;
(c) $\frac{1}{5}$;\;
(d) $\frac{2}{5}$.

\item (a)
\ColFitTable{%
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
$P\backslash Q$ & 1 & 3 & 5\\
\hline
2 & 3 & 5 & 7\\
\hline
4 & 5 & 7 & 9\\
\hline
6 & 7 & 9 & 11\\
\hline
8 & 9 & 11 & 13\\
\hline
\end{tabular}}
(b) $\frac{3}{4}$;\;
(c) $\frac{1}{3}$;\;
(d) $\frac{1}{4}$;\;
(e) $1$.

\item (a)
```
